coredata.dc:description: Utilizing photocatalysis to degrade pollution is emerging as a promising way to treat wastewater, but is challenged by low efficiency and scanty toxicity cognition. In this work, Mn3O4/BiOCl based crystal plane engineering systems are applied for naproxen (NPX) degradation, and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 displayed better degradation rate, which is 16 and 8 times than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and BiOCl010. According to the degradation pathway analysis and biological toxicity experiments, the toxicity of the degradation solution increased first and then decreased, which may be caused by the mineralization of NPX and more toxic intermediates. Affected by the distinct internal charge transfer directions of the two crystal planes of BiOCl, Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system has a faster charge transform than that of Mn3O4/BiOCl001. Moreover, the valence cycle of Mn can further accelerate the charge transfer, which can also provide a powerful driving force for NPX elimination.

head.ce:title: Facet-dependent photoactivity of Mn3O4/BiOCl for naproxen detoxication: Strengthening effect of Mn valence cycle

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Utilizing photocatalysis to degrade pollution is emerging as a promising way to treat wastewater, but is challenged by low efficiency and scanty toxicity cognition. In this work, Mn3O4/BiOCl based crystal plane engineering systems are applied for naproxen (NPX) degradation, and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 displayed better degradation rate, which is 16 and 8 times than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and BiOCl010. According to the degradation pathway analysis and biological toxicity experiments, the toxicity of the degradation solution increased first and then decreased, which may be caused by the mineralization of NPX and more toxic intermediates. Affected by the distinct internal charge transfer directions of the two crystal planes of BiOCl, Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system has a faster charge transform than that of Mn3O4/BiOCl001. Moreover, the valence cycle of Mn can further accelerate the charge transfer, which can also provide a powerful driving force for NPX elimination.

ce:section.ce:para: Naproxen (NPX) is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug used for analgesic and antipyretic properties, especially in patients with rheumatoid arthritis [1,2]. Widely use of NPX for human as well as veterinary disease treatment has led to serious environmental pollution [3–5]. The concentrations of surface waters range from ng/L to μg/L, the low dose and long-term exposure can affect the hatching, development speed, morphology and histopathology of fish [6,7]. Typically, there are three main ways for NPX to enter the environment, including drug waste, hospital wastewater, and excretion through urine after taking drugs [8]. Although it was treated through a sewage treatment plant before entering the environment, less than 5% percentage of NPX can be removed in the wastewater treatment lines [9]. More importantly, the intermediates produced after degradation displayed higher toxicity than the NPX molecule itself in earlier reports [10,11]. Thus, it is important to reduce the toxicity of degradation products while degrading NPX. In the past few years, various methods have been adopted to eliminate NPX pollution, including adsorption [12], membrane filtration [13], ozonation [14] and photocatalysis [15]. Among them, photocatalysis is proven to be a promising technology due to the catalysts are sustainable, environmentally friendly and easily mineralize various organic compounds.

Currently, BiOCl has been believed as a prospective photocatalytic material benefiting from its characteristic layered structure [16–18]. However, BiOCl has the disadvantages of poor light absorption and easy recombination of electrons and holes, which limits its application in photocatalytic degradation [19]. The construction of heterojunction as one of the most common modification method, and BiOCl-based heterojunction has achieved great photocatalytic performance (BiOCl/BiVO4 [20], Cu2WS4/BiOCl [21], and g-C3N4/BiOCl [22] etc). In the heterojunction system, the electron and hole separation of the semiconductor will be significantly improved, and the redox ability of the system will be enhanced [23]. Nevertheless, the layered structure endows its internal electrostatic field, which will change its charge transfer direction with the change of crystal plane [19]. The (001) and (010) facets BiOCl single-crystalline nanosheets were found to have opposite charges transport directions and ultimately affect their photocatalytic degradation activity [24]. Hence, the crystal orientation of semiconductor catalysts will affect the carrier transport direction, which makes it complicated to determine the fate of photogenerated electrons and holes in the process of photocatalysis.

Mn-based species such as MnO2, Mn2O3 and Mn3O4 have drawn massive attention because of their rich redox chemistry, low toxicity, high chemical, and corrosion resistance [25]. Previous studies have shown that BiOCl/Mn3O4 can construct heterojunction system, accelerate electron hole separation, and enhance photocatalytic performance [26]. Moreover, the redox cycles of Mn4+/Mn3+/Mn2+ of Mn3O4 can activation H2O2 by Fenton-like process [27]. In this case, under the action of photogenerated electrons and holes in the photocatalytic system, the valence cycle system of Mn can also be formed [28]. More importantly, in heterojunction system, the transition of Mn valence state can be used as an indicator of charge transfer, which helps us understand the complex charge transfer process between different crystal surfaces.

Hence, we constructed Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction with different crystal planes to explore the effect of Mn valence cycle on the charge transport at the interface at the crystal face engineering heterojunction interface and improve the ability to deal with NPX pollution. The physicochemical properties of Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction systems were obtained through a series of characterization methods. Then the degradation performance of NPX under different conditions was investigated, and the possible intermediate products were analyzed by a liquid chromatograph-mass spectrometer (LC-MS/MS). In addition, the toxicity changes after degradation were evaluated by the biological toxicity experiment. Moreover, the difference in charge transport of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 interfaces and the influence of Mn valence state changes on interface charge transport were analyzed by the density functional theory (DFT) calculation and experimental analysis. Furthermore, the mechanism of photocatalytic degradation and detoxification of NPX in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system was proposed.

Bi(NO3)3·5H2O, ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid disodium and p-benzoquinone (BQ) were purchased from Aladdin industrial Inc. (Shanghai, China). Tetramethylammonium hydroxide was purchased from Sigma–Aldrich (Shanghai, China). MnCl2·4H2O, H2O2 (30%), ethylene glycol KCl, ethanol and isopropanol (IPA) were received from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. (Beijing, China).

The different crystal faces of BiOCl were fabricated according to the previously reported method. Two mmol of Bi(NO3)3·5H2O was completely dissolved in 20 mL of ethylene glycol solution. Then, 20 mL dissolved KCl (2 mmol) slowly dropped into the mixed solution. After stirring for 24 h at room temperature (25 °C), BiOCl010 powder was obtained by washing repeatedly with water and ethanol. Two mmol Bi(NO3)3·5H2O and 2 mmol KCl is completely dispersed in 40 mL of distilled water at room temperature. The solution was poured into an autoclave and then kept at 160 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, BiOCl001 powder was obtained by washing repeatedly with water and ethanol. Then, 1 mmol BiOCl010 and BiOCl001 were dispersed in 30 mL water, and 0.1 mmol MnCl2·4H2O was added and dissolved into suspension under stirring at 25 °C. The pH value of the solution was adjusted to 9 by tetramethylammonium hydroxide, and continue stirring for 30 min. Subsequently, 0.2 mL of H2O2 was added dropwise to the mixed suspension under rapid stirring for 30 min. Finally, the suspension was centrifuged and washed, the precipitates were dried under vacuum freeze-drying to obtain Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001. Mn3O4 monomer was synthesized by the same process except without the addition of BiOCl. The preparation processes of the samples were illustrated in Fig. 1.

The photocatalytic performances of the photocatalysts (50 mg) were evaluated by the degradation of NPX (10 mg/L) with 250 W Xe lamp equipped with an ultraviolet (UV) cut-off filter (λ > 420 nm) and 300 W UV lamp (λ = 254 nm). Meanwhile, the reaction solution is kept stable at 25 °C by a circulating water system. Prior to irradiation, 100 mL catalyst and NPX mixture was stirred in dark for 60 min until the adsorption-desorption equilibrium was reached. One mL degradation solution was sampled every 10 min, then filtered through 0.22 µm PTFE filter membrane and waited for testing.

The exposure experiment of zebrafish embryos (Danio rerio) was used to investigate the toxicity of the degraded solution of NPX. Zebrafish embryos are purchased from Nanjing YiShuLiHua Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Randomly selected zebrafish embryos (24hpf) were divided into six groups, including pure water NPX solution, 15 min, 30 min, 45 min and 60 min degradation solution, and three parallels (15 embryos, 10 mL exposure solution) were included in each group. The exposure solutions were renewed daily and maintained at pH 7.6 ± 0.1. The whole exposure treatments were kept in an illumination incubator for 96 h at temperature of 28 ± 1 °C and photoperiod of 14:10 h light: dark. The dead embryos were removed in time and recorded during the whole exposure period.

All calculations were based on DFT and performed by using the Cambridge Serial Total Energy Package module, employing the ultrasoft pseudo-potential [29]. The exchange–correlation functional at the generalized gradient approximation level was described using the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof for solids functional, which greatly improves the accuracy of PBE for equilibrium properties such as bond length [30,31]. The Kohn–Sham wave functions of the valence electrons were described by a plane-wave basis set with an energy cut-off of 498.8 eV. The Broyden–Fletcher–Goldfarb–Shanno scheme was chosen as the minimization algorithm in the geometric optimization process [32]. The Monkhorst–Pack scheme K-points grid sampling was set as 2 × 2 × 1 for the irreducible Brillouin zone. The atomic coordinates were optimized to obtain structures with an expected accuracy of 0.1 Å and 1.0 deg for bond lengths and angles, respectively. The convergence criteria for structure optimizations were based on the following points: a maximum force tolerance of 0.05 eV Å−1; a maximum stress tolerance of 0.1 GPa; a maximum displacement tolerance of 1 × 10−3 Å and a maximal energy change per atom of 1 × 10−5 eV; and the self-consistent field method tolerance was set as 1 × 10−5 eV/atom.

The composition and phase structure of prepared samples were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD). Fig. 2a illustrates the diffraction peaks at values of 28.99°, 32.41° and 36.04° belonging to (112), (103) and (211) facets of crystalline Mn3O4 phase (matched with JCPDS No. 18-0803) [33]. In addition, all the peaks of BiOCl could be indexed to JCPDS No. 06-0249 and displayed two different crystallization orientations, which could be assigned as BiOCl010 and BiOCl001 [19,24]. All the peaks that appeared in BiOCl could be observed in Mn3O4/BiOCl and no impurity peak was noticed. However, no obvious signals of Mn3O4 could be detected in the Mn3O4/BiOCl, which may be owing to the low crystallinity of Mn3O4 in the samples. In addition, when the molar ratio of Mn to Bi is 3:1, the obvious diffraction peak of Mn3O4 can be observed in the XRD of Mn3O4/BiOCl heterojunction system (Fig. S1). Therefore, the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 heterojunction were successfully prepared. Meanwhile, the surface elemental composition of Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 was explored use X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As shown in Fig. 2b, the XPS survey spectrum confirms the existence of Bi, Cl, O and Mn elements in the surface of the Mn3O4/BiOCl materials. All the binding energies in the XPS spectra have been calibrated by C 1s at 284.8 eV. In the high-resolution Bi 4f XPS spectra (Fig. 2c), two peaks located around 158 and 164 eV could be corresponding to Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2 of Mn3O4/BiOCl001 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010. The two peaks with binding energies at 641.63 and 653.06 eV in Fig. 2d could be assigned to Mn 2P3/2 and Mn 2P1/2 of Mn3O4/BiOCl010, respectively. Whereas the binding energies of Mn3O4/BiOCl system shifted may relate to the interface interaction between Mn3O4 and BiOCl [34]. Besides, for the Cl 2p spectrum shown in Fig. 2e of Mn3O4/BiOCl, the peaks with binding energies located at around 197 and 199 eV, corresponding to Cl 2p1/2 and Cl 2p3/2, respectively. Moreover, the distinguished three peaks of the O 1s spectrum can be assigned to O 1s, Bi-O, and Mn-O (Fig. 2f). In addition, the energy separations of Mn 3s are directly proportional to the valence state of manganese [35]. Meanwhile, the doublet splitting energy of Mn 3s for Mn3O4 is 5.7 eV (Fig. S2), which confirms the formation of Mn3O4 [36]. Noticeably, the negative and positive binding energy shifts may cause the migration of charges at the heterojunction interface, which also means that there is a built-in electric field between the interfaces [37].

The scanning electron microscope (SEM) and transmission electron microscope (TEM) were used to reveal the surface structure and morphological characteristics. The SEM and TEM patterns of BiOCl010 and BiOCl001 exhibit circular nanosheets with diameter of ~100 nm ( Fig. 3a, e) and square nanosheets with diameter larger than 1 µm (Fig. 3b, f), respectively. In addition, it can be seen from the enlarged SEM image in Fig. S3 that BiOCl010 and BiOCl001 have smooth surfaces with thickness of about 20 nm and 80–300 nm, respectively. As illustrated in Fig. 3c, g, and d, h, Mn3O4 ultrathin nanosheets are coated on the surface of BiOCl001 and BiOCl010, forming layered stacking structures. Furthermore, high-resolution TEM images in Fig. 3i, j reveal the highly crystalline nature of the nanosheets. The clear lattice fringes of BiOCl010 and BiOCl001 with the interplanar lattice spacing of 0.275 nm and 0.37 nm correspond to the (110) and (002) atomic planes, respectively [38]. Those results of the lattice spacing are consistent with those crystal face of XRD and correspond to those of BiOCl010 and BiOCl001, respectively. Moreover, the surface cavities of BiOCl010 may be related to the defects on the surface. As expected, EPR analysis in Fig. S4 displayed that BiOCl010 possessed many unpaired electrons with a g-value of 2.0044. Meanwhile, two kinds of the crystal lattice are also observed in Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (Fig. 3k) and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (Fig. 3l), which further indicates that the two crystal forms of BiOCl have been synthesized. Although Mn3O4 is layered on the surface of BiOCl, no obvious lattice spacing is observed, which may be related to its low crystallinity in XRD analysis. Moreover, the EDS mapping images of the Mn3O4/BiOCl heterojunction system were provided in Fig. S5. As we can see from the distribution of elements, Mn3O4 is a thin nanosheet, which is uniformly distributed on BiOCl001 and BiOCl001nanosheets.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Optical absorption, specific surface area and electrochemistry analysis
ce:section.ce:para:
The diffused reflectance spectra (DRS) show the optical properties of the as-prepared samples, as shown in Fig. 4a. The absorption of Mn3O4 is significantly higher than that of the BiOCl010 and BiOCl001. Accordingly, the Mn3O4/BiOCl heterojunctions show remarkable decreases in bandgap and extension of absorption edge towards longer wavelength. The bandgap energies of BiOCl001, BiOCl010, and Mn3O4 can be obtained by using the Tauc approach in the Eq. (1).
(1) αhv = A(hv − Eg)n/2
where α, hv, A, and Eg are the absorption coefficient, discrete photoenergy, constant, and bandgap energy respectively [39] and n value is 1 for BiOCl and 2 for Mn3O4, respectively [34,40]. The estimated Eg values of BiOCl010, BiOCl001, and Mn3O4 were 3.12 eV, 3.18 eV, and 2.14 eV respectively (Fig. 4b). In addition, the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 4c) show classical Type IV isotherms, indicating the mesoporous structure of the samples [41,42]. The specific surface area of BiOCl010 is 20.7 m2/g, which is much higher than that of BiOCl001 (5.87 m2/g). As expected, the small size of BiOCl010 has a larger specific surface area, and its defects and cavities on the atomic layers further increase its specific surface area [43]. At the same time, the specific surface areas of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (23.4 m2/g) and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 (10.7 m2/g) are significantly higher than the corresponding BiOCl, which may be related to the large specific surface area of Mn3O4. In addition, the microporous structures of BiOCl010, BiOCl001, Mn3O4/BiOCl010, and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 were further confirmed by the Horvath–Kawazoe pore size distribution in Fig. 4d [44,45]. Moreover, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was employed to further confirm the electron-transfer rates of as-prepared samples. The semicircle radiuses in the Nyquist plots show the electron transfer resistance, and the material with the lowest radius has the smallest resistances [46,47]. Compared to pristine BiOCl, Mn3O4/BiOCl clearly exhibited smaller resistances in Fig. 4e, which attributed to the rapid transition of photoelectrons between the heterojunction interface [48,49]. In addition, the BiOCl010 with surface defects has lower resistances than that of BiOCl001. As expect, the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 has the highest photocurrent density, approximately 4, 4, and 2 times higher than those of BiOCl001, BiOCl010, and Mn3O4/BiOCl001, respectively (Fig. 4f). Hence, Mn3O4/BiOCl heterostructure completely optimizes the processes of carrier’s separation and transportation, which finally facilitates electron aggregation to enhance the photocatalytic efficiency. More importantly, Mn3O4/BiOCl010 has a faster charge transfer ability than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001, which needs further insight into its mechanism.

The photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated using the degradation of NPX under visible and UV light irradiation, respectively. Before light irradiation, the adsorption of NPX by different catalysts reached equilibrium state. It is found that BiOCl010 has a stronger dark adsorption capacity than that of BiOCl001 and the dark adsorption capacity is further improved after Mn3O4 coating ( Fig. 5), which may be related to the difference of their specific surface areas. As expected, BiOCl001 could hardly be excited by visible-light irradiation, only weak photocatalytic activity was observed as shown in Fig. 5a. Nevertheless, BiOCl010 has stronger photocatalytic performance, and the NPX removal rate is 37.3% in 60 min which may be related to the exposure of crystal face and surface defects. The Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 systems exhibit enhanced photocatalytic activity than that of the BiOCl010 and BiOCl001, and the NPX removal rate by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (95.9%) is much higher than that by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (24.7%). The visible-light photodegradation of NPX may take place via the unpaired electrons on the surface, as seen with BiOCl010, which is strongly dependent on the photoexcitation. In order to verify that the higher visible-light photocatalytic activity of BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 can be mainly attributed to its photoexcitation, we have chosen UV light, which can also excitation BiOCl001. As revealed in Fig. 5b, the performance of the four types of photocatalytic has been significantly improved, and shows the same trend as under visible light, namely Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (98.8%)> Mn3O4/BiOCl001 (88.9%)> BiOCl010 (68.8%)> BiOCl001 (62.7%). Although, UV light can significantly improve the photocatalytic performance of catalysis, no effect on the crystal plane difference of heterojunction. Hence, the better photocatalytic performance of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system may be due to the specific surface area or the heterojunction crystal faces engineering [38]. Therefore, the photocatalytic degradation experiments were conducted again with keeping the same surface area with the BiOCl under visible light. As shown in Fig. 5c. the photocatalytic degradation performance of BiOCl010 decreased significantly, which was similar to that of BiOCl001. Meanwhile, the photodegradation performance of Mn3O4/BiOCl001 does not differ from that in Fig. 5a. Although the performance of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 decreased significantly because the amount of the catalyst is drastically reduced by only 1/4 of the original amount, it still maintains the highest photocatalytic activity among the four catalysts indicating that crystal faces engineering plays the most important role in improving the performance of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system. To evaluate the significance of the heterojunction interaction for the photocatalytic performance of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001, the photocatalytic degradation experiments of the mechanical mixtures Mn3O4 +BiOCl010 and Mn3O4 +BiOCl001 were carried out under visible light. As shown in Fig. 5d, the photocatalytic activities of the mechanical mixtures have only a slight increase than that of the corresponding pure BiOCl, which are much lower than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 heterojunction systems, respectively. This result implies that the interaction between Mn3O4 and BiOCl plays an important role in the improved photocatalytic activity of the Mn3O4/BiOCl heterojunctions. In addition, the degradation process of NPX conforms to pseudo first-order reaction kinetic model, the degradation rate constants (k) of NPX by the as-prepared catalysts under different conditions were displayed in Fig. 5e. Obviously, Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system exhibits better photocatalytic degradation performance, and the degradation rates are 16, 8.5, and 36 times higher than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001, BiOCl010 and BiOCl001, respectively. Furthermore, the total organic carbon (TOC) contents during NPX degradation were also determined (Fig. 5f), the change of TOC removal rates was well matched with the change of NPX degradation rates under different conditions. Meanwhile, the removal rate of TOC can reach to 47% after 60 min of visible light degradation of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system. In order to evaluate the reusability of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system, recycling photodegradation reactions were performed under visible light irradiation. After three times of cycles, only little inactivation of the photocatalysts can be observed in Fig. S6a, which suggest the high reusability of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system. Furthermore, the crystal structures of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction are not changed in Fig. S6b, which clearly suggests that the photocatalyst is highly stable.

The possible degradation intermediates of NPX by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 in 90 min were identified by LC-MS/MS and the degradation pathways of NPX were proposed based on a previous report [50,51]. The total ion chromatogram obtained from the LC-MS/MS is shown in Fig. S7. Multiple peaks were detected after 90 min degradation in Fig. S7a, except for the peak at 4.23 min representing NPX in the solution before degradation in Fig. S7b, which indicates that NPX was completely degraded and many intermediates were produced. By analyzing these peaks, we obtained a lot of chromatographic fragments (Fig. S8) and their possible corresponding degradation products was list in Table S1 according to the reported literature and functional group changes. Meanwhile, the possible degradation pathways for NPX were exhibited in Fig. 6. First, NPX was directly oxidized to generate 8-hydroxy-6-methoxy −2-naphthalenepropionic acid (P1). The methyl group from the methoxy group in the P1 naphthalene molecule was hydrolyze to form 6,8-dihydroxy-2-naphthalenepropionic acid (P2). After a long period of free radical attack, the P2 can be further oxidized to 6,8-dihydroxy-2-naphthoic acid (P3) and naphthalene tetraphenyl (P4). Meanwhile, the propionic acid in the NPX molecule was reduced into propionaldehyde to form 6-hydroxy-2-naphthalene propionaldehyde (P5). The isopropanol on the right side of P5 was further reduced and eliminated H2O decomposed to form 6-hydroxy-2-naphthalene ethylene (P6) and 6-hydroxy-2-naphthalene ethanone (P7), P7 was oxidized to generate 6-hydroxy-2-naphthalenepropylene (P8). Then, methyl group from the methoxy group in the NPX naphthalene molecule was hydrolyzed to form 6-hydroxy-2-naphthalenepropionic acid (P9). The meta and ortho sites of hydroxy in P9 were further attacked by hydroxyl and oxidized to generate 6,7,8-trihydroxy-2-naphthalenepropionic acid (P11), while the (2-naphthalenepropionic acid) P10 formed after hydroxyl lost. In addition, after a long period of free radical attack, the above-mentioned intermediates can be further oxidized to form naphthalene pentaphenol (P12) and naphthalene hexaphenol (P13). The naphtho polyphenols were further oxidized and the naphthalene ring was opened to generate organic small molecules hydroxysuccinic acid (P14), 5-hydroxy-2,4-pentadienoic acid (P15), allyl alcohol (P16), and succinic anhydride (P17). Moreover, these intermediate products are rich in carboxyl and hydroxyl group, and some macromolecular substances (P18-P21) are produced by dehydration reaction. Finally, the organic small molecules were mineralized into CO2 and H2O.

After 96 h of exposure, the survival rates of zebrafish larvae in the degradation solutions of different time are presented in Table S2. Compared to the ultra-pure water control, NPX initial and degraded solutions by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 slightly decrease the survival rates of larvae. However, there is no significant difference among different treatments. The main reason is short exposure time in our toxicity tests, and 10 mg/L of NPX has no obvious acute lethal toxicity to zebrafish embryos. In a previous study, the lowest observed effect concentration of naproxen sodium on common carp (Cyprinus carpio) was estimated to be 10 μg/L by an early-life stage toxicity test for 32 days [6]. In order to evaluate the toxicity changes in the degradation process of NPX upon short-term exposure, more sensitive indicators are needed. It is known that the behavior can reflect the stress to zebrafish. Therefore, the behavioral responses of zebrafish larvae were observed after exposure to NPX initial and degraded solutions for 96 h. Compared with the blank control in Fig. 7a, the trajectories of zebrafish exposed to NPX and its degraded solutions in Fig. 7b–f were sparse, which suggested that zebrafish became inactive. With the extension of degradation time, zebrafish’s activity decreased first and then gradually recovered, which may be related to the degradation of NPX to produce more toxic intermediates. As these intermediate products are further decomposed to produce small organic molecules and eventually mineralized to CO2 and H2O, resulting in reduced toxicity and restoration of zebrafish activity. In addition, the behavioral changes of zebrafish under alternate 5 min light and dark were also recorded in Fig. 7g–h. Obviously, the results of traveled distance and speed were consistent with the behavioral trajectory. The swimming distance and speed of zebrafish under the dark condition (5–10 min, 15–20 min and 25–30 min) is much higher than that under the light condition (0–5 min, 10–15 min and 25–30 min), and zebrafish was inactive under the light condition, which was in line with the reported work [52]. The swimming distance and speed of zebrafish exposed the 90 min degradation solutions (Fig. 7a) did not significantly differ from the control (Fig. 7f) under light conditions. The swimming distance and speed of zebrafish in the solution exposure groups were lower and then higher than that of the blank group in light conditions, which may be the oxidative stress since zebrafish were exposed to the NPX and its degradation solution. Although some intermediate products with stronger toxicity than NPX were produced in the process of photocatalytic degradation, and the NPX solutions degraded for 90 min by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 did not affect zebrafish swimming behaviors. Hence, the more toxicity intermediates and NPX were further degraded and the toxicity decreased, with photodegradation proceed.

Based on the above results for the Mn3O4/BiOCl interfaces, two theoretical models of the interfaces, consisting of Mn3O4 surfaces interfacing with BiOCl001 or BiOCl010 surfaces were built to investigate the interfacial charge transfer mechanisms between Mn3O4 and BiOCl and the hetero-structure interface as follows. For the Layer-BiOCl001-Mn3O4(211) heterostructure, a 6 × 2 unit cell of BiOCl001 with a 2D rectangular cell of 19.43 Å × 7.77 Å and a 2 × 1 unit cell of Mn3O4(211) with a 2D rectangular cell of 20.05 Å × 7.23 Å were chosen. The lattice mismatch was as follows: Δu= −3.09%, Δv= −6.95%. For the Layer- BiOCl010-Mn3O4(211) heterostructure, a 3 × 2 unit cell of BiOCl010 with a 2D rectangular cell of 21.01 Å × 7.77 Å and a 2 × 1 unit cell of Mn3O4(211) with a 2D rectangular cell of 20.05 Å × 7.23 Å were chosen. The lattice mismatch was as follows: Δu= −4.99%, Δv= −6.95%. The two heterostructures were simulated using the slab model, and the vacuum distance between the slabs was set to 20 Å. Mn3O4/BiOCl001 has a better lattice match, but Mn3O4/BiOCl010 has the superior photocatalytic activity. In order to understand this phenomenon, we further studied the interface interaction of these two heterojunctions.

In the computation of the interfacial formation energy, the following Eq. (2) was performed.
(2)
Eformation= EBiOCl/Mn3O4 - (EBiOCl+ EMn3O4)
where EBiOCl and EMn3O4 are the total energy of the relaxed, isolated BiOCl and Mn3O4 slabs in the same supercell when one of the slabs is kept and the other one is replaced by vacuum, respectively. And EBiOCl/Mn3O4 is the total energy of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 interface system. The interfacial binding energy was calculated using the energies of all systems based on the DFT calculation mentioned above. The surface energies and interfacial binding energies of two coherent interface models were lists in Table S3, the negative value of the interface formation energy reflects that the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 have a stable interface. The formation energy of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 is − 21.59 eV and significantly lower than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 (−13.73 eV). Though the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 interface has a better lattice match, the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 interface is more stable. Thus, it can be concluded that the interaction mechanisms of the two interfaces of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 are different. In order to accurately describe and confirm the electron transfer process on the Mn3O4/BiOCl interface, the charge density differences were calculated according to Eq. (3).
(3) Δρ=ρMn3O4/BiOCl-ρMn3O4-ρBiOCl
where ρMn3O4/BiOCl, ρMn3O4, and ρBiOCl were the charge densities of the Mn3O4/BiOCl, Mn3O4, and BiOCl surfaces in the same configuration, respectively. As shown in Fig. 8a, b, the green and yellow areas respectively indicate electron accumulation and depletion. The electrons on the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 tend to migrate to BiOCl010, and the charge distribution of Mn3O4/BiOCl001 has no obvious trend. Meanwhile, in the Mulliken charge population analyses in Fig. S9, the BiOCl010 carry negative charges and the Mn3O4 layers carry positive charges in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 interface, while there is no clear trend in the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 interface. Moreover, the discrepancy of interactions in Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 can be visualized by three-dimensional charge density difference in Fig. 8c. Obviously, charge transfer occurred more significantly on the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 interface. Hence, for Mn3O4/BiOCl010 interface region, the photogenerated electrons in Mn3O4 transfer into the BiOCl; meanwhile, the photogenerated holes in BiOCl are effectively collected at the surfaces of Mn3O4.

By comparing the XPS binding energy of BiOCl with that of the composite Mn3O4/BiOCl in Fig. S10 the negative shifts of the binding energy occurred in Bi, Cl, and O elements of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system compared to BiOCl010, no distinct binding energy shift in Mn3O4/BiOCl001 system compared to BiOCl001. In addition, the comparison of Mn3O4 and Mn3O4/BiOCl of Mn 2p binding energy is shown in Fig. 9a,b. Apparently, the Mn 2p of Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system shifts to higher binding energy compared with pure Mn3O4. By contrast, the binding energy of Mn 2p in the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 system remains unchanged compared to pure Mn3O4. It is known, the negative binding energy shifts of a semiconductor means that electrons are transferred to its surface for enrichment and vice versa [34]. These XPS results suggest that electrons are consumed on Mn3O4 and accumulated on BiOCl010 in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system, which are in line with the DFT calculated result. More importantly, by fitting the peaks of Mn, the valence state changes after the formation of the heterojunction system. In the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system (Fig. 9a), the high-valence Mn4+ increased significantly, while the low-valence Mn2+ decreased. This may be due to the electrons are consumed on Mn3O4 in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system. However, the valence state of Mn in the Mn3O4/BiOCl001 system is irregular, which may be due to the disordered charge transfer between the two semiconductors, as shown in Fig. 9b. Here, we propose the charge transfer law of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 system in Fig. 9c,d. The electron and hole pairs are separated on the surface of Mn3O4, and electrons are transported to the BiOCl010 semiconductor through the heterojunction interface (Fig. 9c). Due to the lateral charge transfer in BiOCl010, the electrons will quickly transfer to the sides, and react with oxygen (O2) in water to form superoxide radicals (·O2 -) [53]. In addition, electron is consumed at Mn3O4, it will cause low valence Mn(n) oxidized to high valence Mn(n+1), and under the action of hydroxyl (-OH), the high valence Mn(n+1) will recover to the low valence Mn(n) and form hydroxyl radical (·OH) (n = 2, 3). Thereby, the cycling system of Mn valence avoids the recombination of electrons and holes, which can significantly enhance the charge transfer and separation, and further enhance the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). In Mn3O4/BiOCl001 system, the charge transfer direction of BiOCl001 is longitudinal, electrons cannot be transferred after being transferred from Mn3O4 to the BiOCl001 surface, and may transfer back to Mn3O4 to recombine with holes [48]. Therefore, the valence change of Mn in this system is disordered in the process of losing and gaining electrons, and electrons and holes are easy to recombine, resulting in a low NPX removal rate (Fig. 5). The valence cycle of Mn has selectivity on the two crystal planes, and can only accelerate the charge transfer on the BiOCl010 plane and enhance the generation of free radicals, which further amplify the difference in the photocatalytic properties of the two crystal planes. Moreover, cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl010 was provided in Fig. S11. There were two redox couples, which represent the valence changes of Mn2+/Mn3+ (−0.1 V vs. Hg/HgO) and Mn3+/Mn4+ (0.8 V vs. Hg/HgO) [54,55]. The shift of the oxidation peak to the right is attributed to consumption of more energy with increasing Mn3+ and Mn3+ content. Meanwhile, the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 exhibits higher redox peak than that of the Mn3O4/BiOCl001, which indicate that the faster valence transition of Mn is in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010. Hence, the CV further confirmed the valence transition of Mn in the Mn3O4/BiOCl010.

In order to further determine the mechanism of the photocatalytic reaction, the free radicals produced in the degradation process were analyzed by electron spin resonance (ESR) technology. There are no signal peaks of DMPO-·OH and DMPO-·O2 - for Mn3O4/BiOCl system in the dark condition ( Fig. 10a,b). In Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system, more superoxide and hydroxyl radicals are produced compared to Mn3O4/BiOCl001, which is consistent with the above results. At the same time, BQ, IPA, and EDTA-2Na are used as scavengers in the trapping experiments to capture ·O2 -, ·OH, and h+, respectively. As shown in Fig. S12, all ·O2 -,·OH, and h+ play important role in the degradation process, in which h+ plays a more important role than the radicals. This confirms the important role of Mn valence state cycle in trapping h+ in the process of photocatalytic degradation of NPX. Moreover. the position of valence band and conduction band of semiconductor were analysis by the Mott-Schottky. As shown in Fig. S13, the flat band potentials of BiOCl010 and Mn3O4 are − 0.37 V and − 0.63 V respectively. Hence, the conduction band of BiOCl010 and Mn3O4 is − 0.37 V and − 0.63 V respectively. Based on band gap value in Fig. 4b, the conduction band and valence band of BiOCl010 and Mn3O4 are − 0.37 eV, 2.75 eV and − 0.63 eV, 0.91 eV, respectively. Based on this, according to the above experimental results, we proposed the activation mechanism of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system (Fig. 10c). Initially, e- and h+ are generated in Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system by excitation of visible light (Eq. (4)). The e- is transferred to BiOCl010, and h+ accumulates on Mn3O4. The electrons accumulated on BiOCl010 react with O2 to form ·O2 - (Eq. (5)). More importantly, h+ will be trapped by low valence Mn(n) to form high valence Mn(n+1), and the high valence Mn(n+1) is highly unstable and reacts with OH- to form ·OH (Eqs. (6 and 7)) [27,56].
(4) Mn3O4/BiOCl010 + hν → Mn3O4/BiOCl010 (e- + h+)
(5) e- + O2 → ·O2 -
(7) Mn(n) + h+ → Mn(n+1) (Holetrape)
(8) Mn(n+1) + OH- → Mn(n) + ·OH (Holerelease)

Therefore, the heterojunction interface formed in Mn3O4/BiOCl010 system can effectively enhance the charge transfer. On the BiOCl010 surface, electrons quickly transfer to the side and generate ·O2 - with O2. Furthermore, the transformations of Mn valence can capture h+ to accelerate the charge transfer and enhance the production of free radicals. The performance difference in crystal surface is further amplified by the valence cycle system of Mn, thereby constructing the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system with better photocatalytic degradation NPX performance.

In summary, Mn3O4/BiOCl010 and Mn3O4/BiOCl001 layered stack systems were synthesized by hydrothermal method. The Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system had better photocatalytic degradation performance on NPX than the Mn3O4/BiOCl001, BiOCl010 and BiOCl001. The path of degradation of intermediate products of NPX by Mn3O4/BiOCl010 is divided into 4 stages. First, the similar molecular intermediates are produced through addition and subtraction of functional groups of NPX. At the same time, these intermediates generate small molecules through ring-opening reaction. Then the small molecular substances will react with NPX or intermediate products to generate some macromolecular substances through esterification, water addition, dehydration. Finally, NPX and all the above intermediates are eventually mineralized to produce H2O and CO2. In addition, we found through biological toxicity experiments that the toxicity will increase during the degradation process, which may be due to the increase in the toxicity of the intermediate product. More importantly, NPX and its intermediate products can mineralization of and the toxicity will eventually decrease. The better photocatalyst performance of the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system is due to its faster charge transfer, which is not only because the charge transfer direction inside the BiOCl010 crystal plane is more conducive to inhibit electron-hole recombination at the heterojunction interface, but also the valence state cycle of Mn will Significantly enhance charge transport and free radical generation. Therefore, the performance difference in crystal surface is further amplified by the valence cycle system of Mn, thereby constructing the Mn3O4/BiOCl010 heterojunction system with better photocatalytic degradation and detoxication performance of NPX.
